Text: O LORD, the God of my salvation, I cry out by day and in the night before You.
Context: This introductory verse sets the tone for the entire psalm, establishing a mood of desperation and earnest pleading to God.

Text: Let my prayer come before You; incline Your ear to my cry.
Context: The psalmist is begging for God’s attention, emphasizing the urgency and depth of his plea.

Text: For my soul is full of troubles, and my life draws near to Sheol.
Context: The speaker is overwhelmed with personal anguish and feels as if he is close to death, which is represented by Sheol – the grave or the abode of the dead.

Text: I am counted among those who go down to the Pit; I am like a man without strength.
Context: The psalmist feels powerless and as good as dead, having no strength to overcome his adversities.

Text: I am set apart with the dead, like the slain who lie in the grave, whom You remember no more, who are cut off from Your care.
Context: This imagery suggests total abandonment by God, as the dead are often perceived to be beyond the realm of God’s providence in ancient beliefs.

Text: You have laid me in the lowest Pit, in the darkest depths.
Context: The speaker accuses God of placing him in a situation of extreme despair and hopelessness.

Text: Your wrath lies heavily upon me; You have overwhelmed me with all Your waves. Selah
Context: The psalmist feels the full weight of God’s anger in a metaphorical sense, as though God’s wrath was a crushing wave.

Text: You have taken from me my closest friends and have made me repulsive to them. I am confined and cannot escape;
Context: The feeling of being utterly alone and trapped is described, with a sense of isolation from even the closest companions.

Text: My eyes are dim with grief. I call to You, O LORD, every day; I spread out my hands to You.
Context: The physical toll of the speaker’s emotional state is depicted, highlighting the daily persistence of his prayer.

Text: Do You work wonders for the dead? Do their spirits rise up and praise You? Selah
Context: The psalmist questions the point of God performing miracles for the dead, which implies that he feels nearly dead and wonders if there is hope for himself.

Text: Is Your loving devotion declared in the grave, Your faithfulness in Abaddon?
Context: Continues the questioning from the previous verse, probing the extent of God’s fidelity and love, even in the place of destruction.

Text: Are Your wonders known in the darkness, or Your righteousness in the land of oblivion?
Context: This rhetorical question asserts that the deeds of God may not be acknowledged in death and obscurity, prompting reflections on the effectiveness of divine justice.

Text: But I cry out to You for help, O LORD; in the morning my prayer comes before You.
Context: Despite questions and despair, the psalmist continues to reach out to God, showing a routine of prayer every morning.

Text: Why, O LORD, do You reject me? Why do You hide Your face from me?
Context: The speaker directly confronts God with his feelings of rejection and divine absence, seeking an explanation for his suffering.

Text: From my youth I have been afflicted and near death; I have borne Your terrors and am in despair.
Context: This historical note explains that the psalmist’s suffering has been a constant in his life, enduring what he perceives to be terror from God.

Text: Your wrath has swept over me; Your terrors have destroyed me.
Context: The intensity of God's wrath is felt as an overwhelming and destructive force.

Text: All day long they surround me like a flood; they have completely engulfed me.
Context: The continuous nature of the psalmist’s trials is compared to an inescapable flood.

Text: You have taken from me friend and neighbor—darkness is my closest friend.
Context: The ultimate sense of loneliness is described, where darkness itself is personified as the psalmist's only companion.
